Hi everyone,
 
Tonight we’ll continue our coverage of the
  tragedy at Virginia Tech. Bob Orr will report new details on the
  investigation into the life of the gunman, Cho Seung-Hui. In
  college, Cho was so introverted that his own roommates barely knew
  him. Sharyn Alfonsi will share her interview with one of the students who
  lived closest to Cho. 
 
Meanwhile, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales was on
  the hot seat in a Senate hearing on the firing of eight federal prosecutors
  who some Democrats say were improperly dismissed. Jim Axelrod will have the
  story. And we’ll have a new CBS News poll on the
  subject. 
 
And Dr. Jon LaPook will share the results of
  research that offers the strongest evidence yet that menopause hormones could
  raise the risk of breast cancer. Rates of the cancer plunged in 2003 after
  millions of women stopped taking hormones and breast cancer rates stayed at
  the lame level in 2004, adding to the evidence against use of menopause
  hormones.
 
And one day after the Supreme Court affirmed the
  legality of the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act, our correspondent Wyatt
  Andrews will take a look at the impact of the ruling. It's the start of
  what is going to be a long, intense debate.
 
Finally, Jerry Bowen will have the story of an
  extraordinary man battling a crippling disease. So far, he’s winning:
  Last week he crossed the finish line of the Boston Marathon. 
 
Thanks, and I hope you’ll join us tonight.
 




Katie Couric
